ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning how to read/discuss scientific papers, more insight into clinical applications of neuroscience
I learned a lot about mental health disorders and ways to address them.
I learned a lot about clinical neuroscience, from the neurological side, the behavioral side, the diagnosis side, and the treatment side.
I learned how to read many scientific papers!
recent research, discussing literature
Feel more comfortable reading research papers
I learned what the field does and does not know, as well as how to critically discuss clinical neuroscience literature

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Holmes is a great professor. Very chill with the reading responses even though the syllabus seems to indicate otherwise. Super knowledgeable and explained difficult concepts clearly. 

Weaknesses: Some jump starts were extremely long (25-30 minutes) which was problematic when 5-6 people had to present per class. This led to rushed discussions towards the end of class and some students not getting enough time to present their jump start. This could be improved by imposing stricter limits on the amount of time per jump start. Sometimes, no one was interested in a particular paper which led to little conversation. Also, there were a lot of readings per week (4-6 papers) so we didn't get to talk about each one in-depth.
The course is mainly run by student presentations, which gives us a chance to discuss the topics anyway we want.

Strengths - I learned a lot!
Weaknesses - It may have been nice to have a very high level overview of each reading given at the start of the class by the professor.

Strengths: Very chill and comfortable environment  where you can discuss psychology and neuroscience topics with other students

Weaknesses: Most of the classes are student led discussions so it can be a little difficult to fully engage in the conversations when you are less familiar with certain topics but prof holmes did a great job of explaining topics that students were less familiar with
you get to discuss interesting papers, great way to learn about added stress

The course is what you put into it. You can get a lot out of it, but also if you dont put it in the work, you can just float. I really liked how we were free to hav e conversations, and it wasnt  too structured

I think a strength was the fact that the class was very focused on discussion which was really nice to be able to hear other people's thoughts and discuss the papers and the results from it. I think a weakness though is that I wish that there was a part of the class where we could learn about the topic focused on for the week and maybe get a little introduction about it. It would have been cool to have a portion of the class that was like an interactive presentation where we heard about general/important knowledge about the field and have a time to hear thoughts about someone who is currently in the field.

Prof Holmes included a wide variety of papers from the field and we were able to talk about each of them in depth. I did not like that even though we were supposed to read the papers prior to class, we spent most of class time summarizing the required readings. I think more time should be spent on discussions and questions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are a neuro (or related) major. It is probably not good for non-STEM students due to how advanced the readings and topics are. It helps to have taken Human Brain and Intro Psych (and other neuro/psych classes).
Yes! Its a good course to fulfill your neuroscience major requirements.
Yes, if you are interested in clinical neuroscience.
Very interesting and insightful course. Good for all who are interesting in learning.
Yes! Great upper psych/nsci seminar
Yes absolutely! Prof Holmes is amazing!
YES! Because Professor Holmes is the coolest guy
yes love the prof
If you are interested in neuro and psychology then yes.

Definitely take this class if you are a neuroscience major interested in human subjects. You get an overview of where the field is with specific areas, such as genetics research, and you also gain an understanding of what the field does not yet know or issues within methodology.
